position.marginalia_text: qui ignis huiusmodi humiditatis colorem augmentat, et siccitate combustionem, donec in finem ducatur [id est] perfectu[m] fiat [etc.]

marginalia.translation: This fire of such humidity increases the colour and the combustion of the concealed dryness until perfection is achieved.

position.marginalia_text: qua[e] putrefaciendo spissantur, putrefaciendi humiditate vi siccitatis, natura[e]q[ue] neq[ue] ipsius: cuius genus est duo lapides de genere lapidu[m]: extractu[m] eni[m] est de lapidibus, qui in quolibet anni tempore generantur. Notetis ergo quod per putrefactione[m] fit inspissatio aquaru[m] [id est] frigidi et humidi, et contra, in siccitatis naturam, quod apparet vt dictum est supra, per putrefactione[m] et generatione[m] in secreto, Accipiamus ergo terra[m] rubea[m] [etc]. Na[m] frigidu[m] et humidum, cum incipit alterari, efficitur nigru[m] vt Carbo. Vnde inquit Hermes in Allegoria sua Lapis n[oste]r inquisitus caret simili, et est citrinus Aureus, extrensecus et intrinsecus. Cum aute[m] corpus eius alteratur, sit nigru[m] et terrebrosum, vt carbones [etc]

marginalia.translation: Through putrefaction inspissation occurs as a result of the conversion of the moist into the dry in its nature not in itself. The type of this is two stones about the type of stones. For it is extracted from the stones, which are produced in the time of some years. Therefore, you shall note that through putrefaction is achieved through inspissation of what, that is cold and humid, and against, in the nature of dryness, what appears that the saying is above, through putrefaction and production in secret. For the cold and wet, when they begin to change, become black like charcoal. So speaks Hermes in his Allegoria.
